phrase.item: Once there was a king.
Along with all his wealth, there was also a sycamore tree near his palace.
[Despite] having all this wealth, the king liked the sycamore tree.
Once the king saw that the sycamore suddenly got dry.
The king became very sad.
He ordered, all the scientists, astrologers, and diviners to be brought to him to figure out the reason why his favorite sycamore was drying up.
After all these groups gathered together, they discovered what would stop the sycamore from drying up.
They said, "A clean woman is needed, she will walk around this sycamore and hug it, and it will grow again from the beginning."
Pokdoman refers to a woman who has never cheated on her husband, a loyal wife.
The king ordered, "On a specific day invite everyone to the square next to the palace, where the sycamore is."
It was announced that, "the King desires the people in his kingdom to bring forth a clean woman.
[For] if she holds the sycamore, it will grow again.
[And] the king will share half of his wealth with this lady."
From somewhere far away village a young man attended the event [lit., invite, i.e. the event to which the king invited everyone].
He loved his wife very much.
He considered his wife to be a very loyal woman.
He stood up from his place and said loudly, "Oh king, my wife is just the clean woman [you need], but my house is very far away."
The king said, "Calculate how many days this young man needs to bring his wife."
The vizier set the exact date.
The vizier told the young man, "On such-and-such a day people will gather together and you can bring your wife."
The young man went back home.
His mother asked him, "Why did the king gather all the kingdom."
Her son replied, "The king's favorite sycamore has dried up."
"The astrologers and diviners said that, if a very loyal woman hugs the sycamore, it will grow again."
"The king has promised that he will give half his wealth to that lady."
"I told the king that my wife is the most loyal woman, and they gave me a time to take my wife there."
His mother thought for a while and said, "Don't tell your wife anything about loyalty, tell her that the king said that any woman who has had affairs with a hundred men should hug the sycamore."
Her son went to his wife and told her that story.
She said, "Oh God, I have been with ninety-nine men,"
"If I had an affair with one more, I would have gotten the [king's] wealth".
The young man's tears were on his face [i.e., he was crying] and he told his mother, "What should I do now?"
"I have promised them [I would come back],"
"Now what should I say to the king?"
His mother thought for a while and said, "Oh my dear son, take the donkey and I will go with you."
This young man listened to his mother, loaded her on the donkey and followed after them.
They got there and [saw] that everyone had already gathered together.
The king saw that the lady wasn't young; an old woman was on the donkey.
He recognized that she was the young man's mother.
The old woman came next to the sycamore, looked at it for a while, hugged it once and one part of the tree turned green [grew].
She hugged it twice and both sides turned green.
She hugged it a third time and it all turned green, but only one leaf on the branch stayed yellow.
Everyone stood up from their places, the king grew happy and said, "Oh mother, why did it all turn green but only one leaf stayed yellow?"
The lady said, "I have never betrayed my husband, only one day our cows came back late from the forest."
zəʂ and ðəʂ are the same and both mean late.
"I didn't ask my husband for permission and went to get the cows, maybe then my husband got upset with me."
"Or maybe he thought [I was doing] something bad."
The king did what he promised.
He loaded a camel with gold and loaded the old woman on top, [put] her son on a horse, and they left.
xətʃir maybe means camel? not sure
They reached home and the boy divorced his wife.
